contentrichtext.text: [[Image:ou ligature.svg|150px|right]] '''Ou''' (Majuscule: {{lang|gr|'''Ȣ'''}}, Minuscule: {{lang|gr|'''ȣ'''}}) is a [[Ligature (typography)|ligature]] of the [[Greek alphabet#Ligatures|Greek letters]] [[omicron|ο]] and [[upsilon|υ]] which was frequently used in [[Byzantine Greek|Byzantine]] manuscripts. This ligature is still seen today on [[icon]] artwork in Greek Orthodox churches, and sometimes in [[graffiti]] or other forms of informal or decorative writing. The ligature is now mostly used in the context of the [[Latin alphabet]], interpreted as a ligature of Latin [[o]] and [[u]]: for example, in the orthography of the [[Wyandot language]] and of [[Algonquian languages]] of [[Western Abnaki language|Western Abenaki]] to represent {{IPA|/ɔ̃/}}, and in [[Algonquin language|Algonquin]] to represent {{IPA|/ɯ/}}. Today, in Western Abenaki, "ô" is preferred, and in Algonquin, "w" is preferred. The ligature, in both majuscule and minuscule forms, is occasionally used to represent minuscule оf "У" in the [[Romanian Cyrillic alphabet|Romanian Transitional Alphabet]], as the glyph for monograph Uk (ꙋ) is rarely available in font sets. The same ligature was also used in the context of [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]]; see [[Uk (Cyrillic)]]. [[Image:Wabikoni.png|thumb|This 1871 Algonquin calendar has "{{Unicode|ȣabikoni kisis}}" for what is today written ''wàbigonì-gìzis'' ("May").]] == Computer encoding == In [[Unicode]], it is encoded for use in Latin as "Latin Capital Script OU" (U+0222 {{unicode|Ȣ}}) and "Latin Small Letter OU" (U+0223, {{unicode|ȣ}}) in the ''Latin Extended-B'' range,<ref>[http://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/0222/index.htm Unicode Character 'LATIN CAPITAL LETTER OU'], [http://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/0223/index.htm Unicode Character 'LATIN SMALL LETTER OU']</ref> and for use in Cyrillic as [[Uk (Cyrillic)|Cyrillic letter monograph Uk]] (uppercase U+A64A, {{Unicode|Ꙋ}}, lowercase U+A64B, {{Unicode|ꙋ}}), in addition to now deprecated "Cyrillic letter Uk" (uppercase U+0478, {{Unicode|Ѹ}}, lowercase U+0479, {{Unicode|ѹ}}), which may be realized with the "о" and "у" either side by side or combined vertically. Despite the ligature's origin in Greek, there is no separate provision for its encoding in the Greek script, because it was deemed to be a mere ligature on the font level but not a separate underlying character. A proposal for encoding it as "Greek letter ou" was made in 1998,<ref>Michael Everson, ''[http://anubis.dkuug.dk/jtc1/sc2/wg2/docs/n1743.pdf Additional Greek characters for the UCS]''</ref> but was rejected.<ref>Nick Nicholas ''[http://www.tlg.uci.edu/~opoudjis/unicode/other_ligatures.html Other ligatures]''.</ref> In older [[character encoding]]s (such as [[ISO 8859]]) and locales where Unicode is not available, it is usually represented by the ''[[8 (number)|8]]'' glyph.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Latin alphabet}} [[Category:Latin alphabet ligatures|Ou]] [[Category:Cyrillic ligatures|Ou]]
